journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Mechanical properties and water absorption of snake grass longitudinal fiber reinforced isophthalic polyester composites

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Kongu Engineering College, Erode, Tamil Nadu, India
2Department of Mechatronics Engineering, Kongu Engineering College, Erode, Tamil Nadu, India

author-notes.corresp: TP Sathishkumar, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Kongu Engineering College, Kongu College Rd, Kumaran Nagar, Erode 638052, Tamil Nadu, India. Email: tpsathish@kongu.ac.in

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Natural fiber reinforced composites have replaced the existing conventional materials due to its light weight and enhanced load-bearing capabilities. In the present work, the newly identified snake grass (Sansevieria ehrenbergii) fiber-reinforced isophthalic polyester composites are prepared by simple hand lay-up method with different fiber weight fractions. The mechanical properties like tensile strength, flexural strength and modulus are analyzed for the longitudinal and transverse direction according to the prescribed standards. The obtained tensile strength and modulus are compared with the theoretically predicted values. The impact strength and energy absorption of the composites are analyzed and compared with control. The water uptake of pure and fiber incorporated resin under varying time period and climatic conditions are examined. The experimental results proves that the composites containing high fiber weight content contribute to remarkable increase in mechanical properties and water absorption capabilities compared to control.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Environmental awareness around the world focuses on the effective usage of the natural fiber reinforced polyester composites for commercial applications. In last two decades, the usage of natural cellulous fibers such as hemp, jute, ramie, sisal, flax, kenaf, cotton, coir, abaca, pineapple, banana, flax, etc., are increased for several applications. Many unknown natural fibers possess good mechanical properties compared to existing fibers.1 The mechanical properties and fiber pullout of randomly oriented snake grass fiber reinforced polyester composites2 and combination of snake grass, coir and banana fibers reinforced hybrid polyester composites3 were increased with different volume fractions. The chemically treated longitudinal fiber reinforced polyester composites have higher tensile strength than the raw fiber composites.4 The mechanical properties of the prepared sisal, jute and coir fiber reinforced polyester/epoxy composites were studied and recommended for usage in household appliances.5 Polyester composites had been developed using green husk coir fiber with different length and content. The results showed that fiber content had major role on the mechanical properties than fiber length.6 The tensile strength of the random and longitudinal oriented sisal7 and jute fiber8 based polyester composites were compared with various volume fractions. The maximum tensile strength was achieved for longitudinally oriented fiber composite. Hemp fiber polyester composites were prepared using resin transfer molding technique. The composites showed remarkable improvement in flexural and impact properties.9 Treated fique fiber was found to have strong interfacial bonding with polyester resin, which indeed resulted in high static and dynamic mechanical properties.10 The interlaminar shear strength of jute fiber was improved by chemical treatment.11 The physical and mechanical properties of sisal fiber12 and banana fiber13 reinforced thermoset and plastic composites were compared with the theoretical models.

The water and chemical solvent was used as absorption medium to examine the mechanical properties of coir fiber polyester composites.14 The water absorption of polyester–sisal fiber composites prepared using different surface modifiers was analyzed.15 Kinetics of water absorption in hemp fiber,16 woven banana fiber17 polyester composites and lantana camara fiber epoxy composites18 were studied. The mechanical properties of roselle/sisal polyester hybrid composites were decreased after water absorption.19 The thermal and mechanical properties of random and quasi-unidirectional oriented phormium tenax fiber epoxy composites were studied. The maximum mechanical properties was found in unidirectional than random orientation.20 The effect of fiber length and fiber content on the mechanical properties of banana fiber epoxy composites21 and Sansevieria cylindrica fiber polyester composites22 were examined. With regard to application aspects, different interior and exterior components of the automobiles23 can be replaced with the help of natural fiber reinforced composites.

Many research works had been carried out on natural fiber based polymer composites, but the studies on the development of snake grass fiber based composite constitutes in lesser dimension. The main objective of this article is to prepare the longitudinal snake grass fiber reinforced polyester composites (LSGC). Mechanical properties and water absorption of the prepared composites at different climatic conditions has been analyzed. In addition, the obtained experimental tensile strength and modulus are compared with theoretically predicted values.

sec.title: Snake grass fiber (S. ehrenbergii fiber) and resin
sec.p:
Snake grass fibers, which are abundantly available in Tamilnadu, southern part of the India, are extracted by the simple water retting process. Commercially available isophthalic unsaturated polyester resin, accelerator – methyl ethyl ketone peroxide (MEKP) and catalyst – cobalt naphthalene are used for the composite preparation. The distinctive properties of the isophthalic polyester resin and fiber are shown in Tables 1 and 2. Table 1.
The distinctive properties of the isophthalic polyester resin.
S. No Properties Unit Range
1. Specific gravity – 1.1–1.46
2. Density kg/m3 1125
3. Tensile strength as per ASTM standard MPa 16–18
4. Tensile modulus as per ASTM standard GPa 0.25–0.4
5. Compressive strength MPa 90–250
6. Flexural strength as per ASTM standard MPa 30
7. Flexural modulus as per ASTM standard GPa 1.1–1.4
8. Shrinkage % 0.004–0.008
Table 2.
The physical and tensile properties of snake grass fiber.
Properties Snake grass fiber
Density (kg/m3) 887
Diameter (µm) 45–250
Tensile strength (MPa) 240–450
Tensile modulus (GPa) 6.42
%Elongation 2.87

sec.title: Composite preparation
sec.p:
The simple hand lay-up technique is adapted to prepare the composite specimen with various weight contents likes 10%, 20%, 30% and 40%, respectively. About 1% of catalyst and accelerators are used to cure the isophthalic polyester resin.2,3 Steel dies are designed to prepare the composite specimens. Fiber orientation and uniformity in the composites is maintained by longitudinal fiber orientation attachment to achieve the unidirectional material property. The resin is poured over the fiber in female die and two rollers are used to entrap all the air bubbles. Then the closed mould is kept on the hydraulic press and the compressive pressure is applied for 4 h at atmospheric temperature. Finally the fibers are reinforced with the polyester resin within the mould cavity of dimensions 300 × 300 × 3 mm3. The composite plate is then post-cured for 1 h in oven and the final shape of the composite plate is obtained. The longitudinal oriented snake grass fiber reinforced composites as shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Longitudinal oriented snake grass fiber reinforced composites plate.

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p: Mechanical properties such as tensile, flexural and impact properties are measured based on the ASTM standards. The tensile properties are measured based on the ASTM D 638 standards4,18 and the sample size is 165 × 12.7 × 3 mm3.18 The electronic tensometer setup is used to perform the tensile testing with a cross-head speed of 1 mm/min using the load cell of 5 kN. Three-point bending testing is used to measure the flexural properties as per ASTM D 790 standards. The sample size is 48 × 12.7 × 3 mm3 with the depth to width ratio of 16:1. In bending test, the load cell of 2 kN is used with the cross head speed of 2.5 mm/min. The impact properties are measured based on ASTM D-256.6,8,15 The sample size is 64 × 12.7 × 3 mm3. Five specimens are used for testing and the average values of the properties are reported in this article.

sec.title: Water absorption of composites
sec.p: Water absorption tests are carried out with different time periods and different climatic conditions such as cold at 10℃, room temperature (25℃) and hot at 60℃.15 The specimens are prepared based on ASTM D570 standard. The sample size is 64 × 12.7 × 3 mm3.20 The specimens are taken periodically and a tissue paper is used to remove the surface water of the composites. The percentage of weight absorption is calculated at different time intervals.18,19

The percentage weight gain of water absorption in the composites is calculated at different time interval by using the following equation.17,18 (1) %M=(Wt-Wo)Wo×100 where Wo and Wt denotes the initial dry weight of the sample and weight of the sample after specific time (t) in water.

sec.title: Scanning electron microscope
sec.p: The fracture morphology of pure resin, untreated and treated SGFs composites are examined using scanning electron microscope (SEM, model: JEOL JSM-6390). The facture zones of the specimens are cut into dimension of 1 × 1 cm2. The fracture ends of the tensile and impact specimens of the composites are mounted on aluminium stubs in SEM machine for taking image.

sec.title: Effect of longitudinal tensile strength and modulus of the longitudinal snake grass fiber reinforced composites
sec.p:
The tensile properties of the LSGC are measured for the various fiber Wf and the resulting plots and SEM images are shown in Figures 2 to 6. Figure 2 shows the variation of longitudinal tensile strength versus tensile strain of LSGC. The stress increases linearly with respect to strain for all Wf cases. The increase in fiber Wf shows increase in tensile strength and strain. In tensile strength, the percentage increase between the pure resin to 10%, 20%, 30%, 40% and 50%Wf are 56.8%, 72.8%, 79.9%, 83.2% and 78.60%, respectively. However, very marginal increase in tensile strength has been observed for the fiber loading above 30%Wf. The obtained tensile strength is found much higher as compared to the earlier reported.4 Similarly in tensile strain, the percentage increases between the pure resin to the corresponding Wf are 14.9%, 33.4%, 44%, 51.3% and 44%, respectively. The increase in Wf leads to more fiber accumulation in the composites. The breakage of composites in the beginning takes little more strain to failure due to less interaction between fiber and matrix at higher tensile load. Figure 2.
Longitudinal tensile stress versus strain of LSGC.
LSGC: longitudinal snake grass fiber reinforced polyester composites.
Figure 6.
Transverse tensile properties of LSGC.
LSGC: longitudinal snake grass fiber reinforced polyester composites.

The maximum tensile strength and strain has been observed for the 40%Wf fiber loaded composite (Figure 3). Gradual increase in loading of fiber in the resin leads to gradual increase in tensile modulus. The percentage improvements in tensile modulus between the pure resin to the corresponding Wf of composites are 49.3%, 59.2%, 64.7% and 65.6% respectively. The improvement in modulus is higher compared to earlier report.4 The tensile strength, modulus and elongation at break of the composites shows 6, 2.9 and 2 times higher compared to pure resin. Hence, it proves that addition of fiber in the resin significantly increases the tensile strength of the composite. But more fiber (50%Wf) in the composites decreases the tensile properties. The SEM image of the tensile fracture specimen and pure resin are shown in Figure 4. The fibers and fibers pull out is more in composites. The obtained results for the longitudinally oriented fiber reinforced polyester composites are compared with the polyester composites containing randomly oriented short fibers2 with same Wf. The percentage improvement between them is 118.4 and 97.1 for tensile strength and modulus. Hence the tensile properties of longitudinally oriented fiber reinforced polyester composites in longitudinal direction are higher than the randomly oriented short fiber composites. Figure 3.
Longitudinal tensile properties of LSGC.
LSGC: longitudinal snake grass fiber reinforced polyester composites.
Figure 4.
The SEM image of tensile fractured specimen: (a) pure resin and (b) 40%Wf of fiber.
SEM: scanning electron microscopy.

Specific tensile strength and modulus of pure and fiber-filled resin are shown in Figure 5. Specific tensile strength of LSGC increases linearly with increase in Wf of fiber. Highest tensile strength is found for the composites containing 40%Wf of fiber. The percentage improvements in specific tensile strength between the pure resin and corresponding Wf are 57.4%, 75%, 82.4% and 85.9%, respectively. The specific tensile modulus also increases linearly with respect to Wf of snake grass fiber for all composites. The percentage improvement between the resin and corresponding Wf are 54.6%, 64.9%, 70.9% and 72.7%, respectively. Figure 5.
Longitudinal specific tensile modulus and strength versus volume fraction of LSGC.
LSGC: longitudinal snake grass fiber reinforced polyester composites.

sec.title: Effect of transverse tensile strength and modulus of the LSGC
sec.p: The transverse tensile strength of LSGC is shown in Figure 6. Increasing the fiber Wf decreases the tensile strength of the composite. Resin containing 40%Wf fiber shows 10.2% decrease in tensile strength compared to pure resin and 6.3 times lesser than the value obtained for longitudinal direction. Also increasing the fiber Wf (50%) in composites leads to decrease the strength and modulus. The percentage improvement of transverse tensile modulus between the pure resin to 40%Wf is 24.1% and it is 2.2 times less than the longitudinal tensile strength of composites. Increase in fiber Wf shows gradual increase in tensile modulus. The obtained transverse tensile strength of unidirectional fiber composite is 7 to 8 times lesser than the tensile strength of longitudinal direction.8

sec.title: Comparison of experimental and theoretically predicted tensile strength
sec.p:
The experimental and theoretical value of longitudinal and transverse tensile strength of LSGC is shown in Figures 7 and 8. Figure 7 shows the composite strength versus volume fraction (Vf) of the longitudinal fiber composites. The theoretically predicted tensile strength is higher than the experimental values of unidirectional oriented fiber composite. The percentage difference between the theoretical and experimental tensile strength of longitudinally oriented fiber composites are 20.5% for 13.5%Vf, 27.3% for 27%Vf, 25.9% at 40%Vf and 27.9% at 51%Vf, respectively. The obtained result shows high deviation between the experimental and theoretical values. High fiber loading in resin leads to less adhesion between the fiber and matrix. Hence, fiber pullout is more for composites containing high fiber content. The obtained transverse tensile strength of LSGC also reveals similar results. The theoretical transverse tensile strength is less than the experimental values for all fiber Vf. The theoretical values are obtained by using the rule of mixture of longitudinal fiber composite.12,24 Figure 7.
Composite strength versus volume fraction (Vf) of LSGC.
LSGC: longitudinal snake grass fiber reinforced polyester composites.
Figure 8.
Composite modulus versus volume fraction of LSGC.
LSGC: longitudinal snake grass fiber reinforced polyester composites.
Longitudinal mixture (2)σLC=σfVf+σmVm (3)ELC=EfVf+EmVm

Transverse mixture (4)σTC=σm[1-Vf×(1-(Em/Ef))1-(4Vf/π)×[1-(Em/Ef)]] (5)ETC=1VfEf+VmEm where σLC, σTC, σf and σm are strength of composite, fiber and matrix expressed in MPa, ELC, ETC, Ef and Em are Young’s modulus of composite, fiber and matrix expressed in GPa, VC, Vf and Vm are volume fraction of the composite, fiber and matrix, respectively. T and C are transverse and longitudinal fiber composite, respectively.

Figure 8 shows the experimental and theoretical Young’s modulus values for the unidirectional fiber reinforced composites. The experimental Young’s modulus tested in longitudinal direction is less compared to theoretical modulus and higher than transverse modulus of the composite. The result shows that the experimental Young’s modulus lie in between the theoretical Young’s modulus of matrix and fiber. Theoretically calculated longitudinal Young’s modulus at 40% Vf is 48.6% higher and transverse Young’s modulus at 40%Vf is 13.7% higher than the experimental values. The fiber accumulation increases the fiber matrix delamination very quickly in the composite testing. The experimental value is studied up to 51%Vf because if the Vf increases more than a critical value the thickness of the composite also increases and the matrix dispersion is not uniform during composite preparation.

sec.title: Effect of impact strength of the LSGC
sec.p:
Figure 9 shows the impact strength of LSGC. The impact resistance increases linearly with increasing fiber Wf. The percentage improvement between the resin to the Wf of fiber-filled composites are 47.2%, 60.8%, 68.7%, 72.9% and 66.5%, respectively. The maximum improvement is achieved for the 40% Wf fiber loaded composites, which is 3.7 times greater than the pure resin. The percentage improvements between the Wf of fiber loaded composites are 29.7%, 21.4%, 13.2% and −23.26%, respectively. It is found that the percentage improvement decreases with increase in Wf of fiber. Figure 9.
Impact resistance and energy versus fiber weight fraction of LSGC.
LSGC: longitudinal snake grass fiber reinforced polyester composites.

The impact energy increases linearly with increasing Wf of fiber. The percentage improvement between the pure resin to Wf are 44.4%, 60.9%, 68.9%, 73% and 57.3%, respectively. The impact energy of composite in 40% Wf of snake grass fiber content is 3.7 times higher than pure resin. So the maximum improvement between the pure resin to 40%Wf is 73%. The impact resistance and energy is increased with fiber Wf. The impact load is evenly distributed in unidirectional fiber composites. The higher fiber content leads to more crack path and absorb more energy. Hence the composites can sustain maximum dynamic load due to the maximum fiber content present (40%Wf) in the composites. If the fiber Wf is more than 40%, it decreases the impact properties. The SEM image of impact fractured specimen of the pure resin and fiber containing composites are shown in Figure 10. The fiber and fiber pull out is more in the fracture zone of the specimen. Figure 10.
The SEM image of impact fractured specimen: (a) pure resin and (b) 40%Wf of fiber.
SEM: scanning electron microscopy.

sec.title: Effect of flexural strength of LSGC
sec.p:
Figures 11 and 12 show the longitudinal flexural strength and modulus of LSGC. Figure 11 shows the flexural strength versus strain for the LSGC and it is almost increases with increase in strain. It is absorbed that the flexural strength gradually increases with increase in fiber Wf of the composites. The percentage improvement between the resin and Wf of fiber containing composites are 22.2%, 61.8%, 80.5%, 82.5% and 77.56%, respectively. The flexural load increases with increase in Wf and the maximum load of 200 N is obtained at 40% Wf, which is 5.7 times greater than the pure resin. The flexural strain increases with increment in weight fraction of fiber. Maximum strain rate of 5.6% is obtained at 40%Wf. The improvement in strain rate between the pure resin to 40%Wf is 37.7%. The flexural strength does not show much improvement for fiber Wf beyond 30%. This may be due to less quantity of matrix isolated in the composite. The maximum flexural strength and strain is obtained at 40%Wf fiber containing composite and it is 5.7 times greater than the pure resin. Figure 11.
Flexural strength versus strain of LSGC.
LSGC: longitudinal snake grass fiber reinforced polyester composites.
Figure 12.
Longitudinal flexural properties of LSGC.
LSGC: longitudinal snake grass fiber reinforced polyester composites.

In Figure 12, the flexural modulus increases linearly with increasing fiber Wf. The percentage improvement of modulus between the resin and Wf of fiber containing composites are 25.8%, 57.1%, 70%, 82.5% and 65.6%, respectively. The maximum flexural modulus is obtained for 40%Wf, which is 3.6 times greater than the pure resin. It is clear that the less adhesion between the fibers and polyester is the reason for more strain to failure and maximum fiber pullout. Also the flexural properties of the longitudinally oriented fiber reinforced polyester composites in longitudinal direction are higher than the randomly oriented short fiber composites.2 The percentage improvement between them is 15.75 and 32.43 for flexural strength and modulus, respectively.

sec.title: Effect of water absorption of the LSGC
sec.p:
The trends of moisture absorption for 10%, 20%, 30% and 40% Wf of LSGC under different environmental conditions are shown in Figure 13. The average values of three specimens are considered to plot the curve for all the composites. The maximum water absorption takes place at higher fiber loading composites. For all the three environmental conditions, the maximum water absorption is obtained at 40%Wf. However, the initial rate of water absorption is found higher at hot condition (60℃) (Figure 13(c)). The acceleration of water uptake of LSGC is based on four factors such as hydrophilicity of fiber cellulous, lumen, microcracks in fiber and adhesion between fiber and matrix. The Wf of fiber in the composites is responsible for increase in the number of free OH groups. It comes into contact with the moisture and forms hydrogen bonding which results in more swelling. It can be clearly seen that the water absorption normally increases with immersion time. The weight of the composite is not found to increase more than a certain value beyond the saturation point. The acceleration of diffusion of water molecules into the composite is purely time and temperature dependent. Elevated temperature increases the activation of diffusion due to formation of microcracks or voids in the composites, which in turn weakens the adhesion between the fiber and matrix. In these three conditions, the time taken for reaching the saturation point of water absorption is not equal. The saturation time is approximately 80 h, 60 h, 40 h under cold, normal and hot water absorptions. The maximum water absorption for 40%Wf is 14.2%, 20.9%, 34.2% under cold, normal and hot water, respectively. The percentage of water observed for all composites is listed in Table 3. The percentage absorption of water for the fiber-filled composites enhances with increasing Wf. Composites containing fibers of 20%, 30%, 40%Wf shows 119.8%, 256%, 412% (cold water) 128.6%, 261.8%, 429.4% (normal water) and 180.7%, 401.3%, 632.7% (hot water) increase in water uptake compared to 10%Wf of fiber-filled composites (Figure 13). From the experimental results, it proves that rate of water absorption increases with temperature and time. Figure 13.
Water absorption versus square root of time period of LSGC at different conditions.
LSGC: longitudinal snake grass fiber reinforced polyester composites.
Table 3.
The water absorption properties of LSGC in different environmental conditions.
Environment Fiber Wf (%) M (%) Kinetics of water absorption Transports coefficients
n k Diffusion coefficient × 10−10 (D) (m2/min) Sorption coefficient (S) (g/g) Permeability coefficient P) (m2/min)
Cold water at 10℃ 10 2.78 0.50310 0.15338 1.9778 0.027778 5.4939 × 10−12
20 6.11 0.43030 0.20189 3.5087 0.061111 2.1442 × 10−11
30 9.92 0.42705 0.18300 5.0359 0.099237 4.9975 × 10−11
40 14.24 0.34125 0.25910 5.9202 0.142433 8.4323 × 10−11
Normal water at atmospheric 10 3.95 0.66851 0.11190 2.5365 0.041121 1.0430 × 10−11
20 9.03 0.45222 0.16588 3.3654 0.099236 3.3397 × 10−11
30 14.29 0.38153 0.22458 5.4453 0.166666 9.0754 × 10−11
40 20.91 0.45780 0.18279 7.8753 0.264406 2.0822 × 10−10
Hot water at 60℃ 10 4.67 0.68561 0.11206 2.6050 0.046729 1.2173 × 10−11

30 23.41 0.54562 0.16255 8.3768 0.233766 1.9582 × 10−10
40 34.22 0.29920 0.32315 0.1248 0.341935 4.2690 × 10−10

sec.title: Kinetics of water absorption
sec.p: The kinetics and diffusion mechanism of water absorptions are obtained based on curve fitting using the experimental values and Fickans theory.15,17 The values of n and k are essential factors which are analyzed from the following equation.15,17 (6)log[MtMm]=logk+nlogt

In equation (6), k and n are constant and explains the mechanism of diffusion which takes place inside the natural fiber reinforced polyester composite. In Table 3, the value of k and n constants explains the mechanism of diffusion that takes place inside the natural fiber reinforced polyester composites. The k denotes the interaction between the polymer and water, n denotes the mode of diffusion take place in the composites. The value of n should lie in between 0 and 1. If the value of n = 0.5, the diffusion is Fickian, from 0.5 ∼ 1, the diffusion is non-Fickian and n > 1, the diffusion is said to be anomalous.15,18 The values of n and k for water sorption for the LSGC are given in Table 3. The low and high value of n clearly shows that the mechanism of transport deviates from the Fickian. The fiber Wf increases with decrease in n values. It is also clear that the n value deviates from the Fickian, which results in more diffusion of water absorption further improving molecular motion in the composites. The percentage of water absorption is increased at higher temperatures and it can be attributed to the relaxation mechanism in the polymer for distorting the polymer network.18 Also k values increases the water–polymer interaction in the composites.

sec.title: Transport coefficients in water absorption
sec.p: The transport coefficients are determined for all environmental conditions. The diffusion coefficient (D)15,17,18 is the most important parameter of Fickian model, which explains the penetration of water molecules inside the composite. ‘D’ can be obtained by values measured from the curve of moisture absorption in percentage (M) with square root of time taken. In this the initial linear portion of the curve fit is consistent with Boltzman’s solution.17 The following equation is used to determine the D value. (7)MtMm=4πtDXh2 where Mm is the equilibrium absorption of moisture content in the sample, Mt is the moisture content at a specified time t, Dx is the moisture diffusion coefficient and h is the sample thickness. The ability of water molecules to imprecate among the polymer segments is determined by the diffusion coefficient. Finally, the diffusion coefficient can be calculated from the following equation.15,17,20 (8)D=π[h4Mm]2[M2-M1t2-t1]2 where t1 and t2 are selected square root of time taken for water absorption of points in the initial linear portion, M2 and M1 is the respective percentage of moisture content at time t1,2.17 The fiber Wf increases the diffusion coefficient (Table 3). The diffusion coefficient for the hot water absorption is found to be higher compared to cold and normal water absorption. The higher fiber loading of LSGC can have higher cellulous content which leads to greater diffusivity. The hot water can quickly diffuse inside the composites, where it entraps inside fiber cellulose and polymer chains. Hence, it results in more diffusivity values. The permeability of small water molecules into the polymer is dependent on diffusion and sorption or solubility17,18 of the liquid in the polymer.

The sorption coefficients can be calculated by the following equation. (9)S=M∞Mp where S is the sorption coefficient, M∞ is the mass of the water molecules taken up at equilibrium swelling and Mp is the initial mass of the polymer sample.

The value of sorption coefficient (S) of the LSGC is given in Table 3. The increase in fiber Wf increases the value of S i.e. the water molecules absorbed in the composites are more. The permeability (P) is the product of sorption and diffusion coefficient.
The permeability of the polymer composite to water absorption can be expressed by the following equation. (10)P=S×D

Table 3 gives the values of permeability coefficient of fiber Wf of the composites. The increase in permeability leads to less fiber–matrix interaction and also the presence of more fiber content in the composites.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The LSGC is prepared with various fiber Wf. The mechanical properties and water uptake under different environmental conditions are analyzed. The following conclusions are obtained from the experimental and theoretical observations.
The tensile strength and modulus of the LSGC improves with gradual increase in fiber weight fractions of the composites. The maximum values are achieved for composites containing 40%Wf of fiber. The composites are subjected to longitudinal and transverse modes of testing. The results show that the longitudinal tensile strength and modulus are comparatively higher than the transverse values of LSGC. Theoretically predicted tensile strength and modulus of LSGC are higher than the obtained experimental values. Also the mechanical properties of the longitudinally oriented fiber reinforced polyester composites are higher than the randomly oriented short fiber composites.
The flexural strength and modulus of LSGC increases with increase in Wf of fiber. Composites containing 40%Wf fiber shows maximum flexural strength and modulus. The strain rate has been found higher for more fiber containing composites.
The impact load is applied on the composite specimens perpendicular to the fiber direction, which absorbs more impact energy. The impact resistance and energy gradually increases with increase in fiber Wf. The maximum properties are obtained at 40%Wf.
In water absorption, the percentage of moisture absorption, mode of diffusion, sorption and permeability coefficients increases with gradual increase in fiber Wf the composites and immersion time. From the extensive analysis results, it shows that hot water absorption is predominantly higher than the other two. Hence, the optimum weight fraction of LSGC is achieved for 40%Wf fiber containing composites.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.
